{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:1813 title page Vindication Diet.jpg|thumb|1813 title page, printed for J. Callow by Smith & Davy, London.]]{{italic title}} '''''A Vindication of Natural Diet''''' is an 1813 book by [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]] on [[vegetarianism]] and [[animal rights]]. It was first written as part of the notes to ''[[Queen Mab (poem)|Queen Mab]]'', which was privately printed in 1813. Later in the same year the essay was separately published as a pamphlet.
==Background==
Shelley wrote four essays on the subject of vegetarianism, "A Vindication of Natural Diet" (1813), the note in ''[[Queen Mab (poem)|Queen Mab]]'', in a section of "A Refutation of Deism" (1814), and "On the Vegetable System of Diet", which was published posthumously in 1929.<ref>Spencer, Colin. ''The Heretic's Feast: A History of Vegetarianism''. Great Britain: Hartnolls Ltd, Bodmin. 1993, pp. 244–45.</ref><ref>Morton, Timothy, "Joseph Ritson, Percy Shelley and the Making of Romantic Vegetarianism." ''Romanticism'', Vol. 12, Issue 1, 2006, pp. 52–61.</ref><ref>Clark, David Lee. "The Date and Source of Shelley's 'A Vindication of Natural Diet'." ''Studies in Philology'', Vol. 36, No. 1, January 1939.</ref> Shelley first experimented with a vegetarian diet while at [[Oxford University]] according to [[Thomas Jefferson Hogg]].<ref>Hogg, Thomas Jefferson. ''The Life of Percy Bysshe Shelley.'' London, 1858, I, p. 238.</ref> Shelley began a vegetarian diet on 1 March 1812 along with his first wife Harriet Westbrook. Shelley began composing the essay in October–November 1812.
The work has been republished since 1813 beginning with an abridged version which was published in Boston by March, Capen, and Lyon in an American collection ''Vegetable Diet: As Sanctioned by Medical Men, and by Experience in All Ages'', edited by William A. Alcott.<ref>[http://dbooks.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/books/PDFs/600037532.pdf ''Vegetable Diet''. Bodleian Libraries. University of Oxford.]</ref>
The essay was reprinted in 1884 in a new edition in London by F. Pitman and by John Heywood and the Vegetarian Society in Manchester. The original title page was reproduced: ''A Vindication of Natural Diet. Being One in a Series of Notes to Queen Mab (A Philosophical Poem).'' London: Printed for J. Callow by Smith & Davy, 1813. The new edition featured a preface by [[Henry Stephens Salt]] and [[William Axon]]. A second edition appeared in 1886.
In 1904, the work was republished in London by C. W. Daniel as ''A Vindication of Natural Diet and Extracts from the Works of Dr. Lambe'', edited and annotated by F. E. Worland.
==Vegetarianism==
Shelley wrote in ''A Vindication of Natural Diet'': "It is only by softening and disguising dead flesh by culinary preparation that it is rendered susceptible of mastication or digestion, and that the sight of its bloody juices and raw horror does not excite intolerable loathing and disgust."<ref name="Shelley, Percy Bysshe 1813, pp. 1">Shelley, Percy Bysshe, "A Vindication of Natural Diet;" London: Smith & Davy. 1813, pp. 1–36.</ref>
Shelley used the imagery of slaughtering a lamb. In ''[[Queen Mab (poem)|Queen Mab: A Philosophical Poem]]'' (1813) he wrote about the change to a vegetarian diet using the lamb imagery: "And man ... no longer now/ He slays the lamb that looks him in the face,/ And horribly devours his mangled flesh."<ref>Preece, Rod. ''Sins of the Flesh: A History of Ethical Vegetarian Thought''. Vancouver, BC, Canada: University of British Columbia Press, 2008.</ref>
In the novel ''[[Frankenstein|Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus]]'' (1818), which Shelley collaborated on,<ref>Adams, Stephen. "Percy Bysshe Shelley helped wife Mary write Frankenstein, claims professor: Mary Shelley received extensive help in writing Frankenstein from her husband, Percy Bysshe Shelley, a leading academic has claimed", ''The Telegraph, 24 August 2008.</ref><ref>Grande, James. Review: The Original Frankenstein, By Mary Shelley with Percy Shelley ed Charles E Robinson. "To what extent did Percy Bysshe Shelley work on 'Frankenstein'? A new analysis reveals all", ''The Independent'', 16 November 2008.</ref> the Monster is portrayed as a vegetarian. The lamb imagery is retained. The Monster explained his vegetarian diet to [[Victor Frankenstein]]: "My food is not that of man. I do not destroy the lamb and the kid to glut my appetite; acorns and berries afford me sufficient nourishment."
In "The Sensitive Plant" he argued that all life forms, including "all killing insects and gnawing worms,/ And things of obscene and unlovely forms", have a natural role to play in the ecosystem which requires understanding rather than destruction, because what they do "although they did ill, was innocent".<ref>[https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/p-b-shelleys-a-vindication-of-the-natural-diet P. B. Shelley's "A Vindication of the Natural Diet". British Library.]</ref>
In ''Laon and Cythna'', republished as ''[[The Revolt of Islam]]'' (1817), Fifth Canto, the Festival of nations held after the Revolution is a banquet where no meat is served. The feast is vegetarian: "Never again may blood of bird or beast/ Stain with its venomous stream a human feast". This is "The banquet of the free" where the guests are described as "reclining as they ate, of Liberty,/ And Hope, and Justice". The festival was not polluted by gore, "But piled on high, an overflowing store/ Of pomegranates, and citrons, fairest fruit,/ Melons, and dates, and figs, and many a root".<ref>[http://spenserians.cath.vt.edu/TextRecord.php?action=GET&textsid=36173 ''Revolt of Islam''. Canto Fifth.]</ref>
Shelley argued that eating meat was unnatural. He maintained that diseases and immorality arose from mankind's "unnatural habits of life". A meatless diet was the best regimen for maintaining a healthy and disease-free lifestyle. He wrote that human diseases could be decreased by a return to a natural vegetable diet.<ref>Spencer, Colin, ''The Heretic's Feast: A History of Vegetarianism;'' Great Britain: Hartnolls Ltd, Bodmin. 1993, pp. 244–45.</ref> Shelley argued that eating meat was a practice that polluted the body with syphilis and resulted in other ailments. In ''A Vindication of Natural Diet'' he wrote, "Should ever a physician be born with the genius of [[John Locke|Locke]], I am persuaded that he might trace all bodily and mental derangements to our unnatural habits,"<ref name="Shelley, Percy Bysshe 1813, pp 16">Shelley, Percy Bysshe, "A Vindication of Natural Diet"; London: Smith & Davy. 1813, p. 16.</ref> these unnatural habits being the consumption of meat. He cited the [[allegory]] of [[Prometheus]] who stole fire from the gods which enabled mankind to cook meat, thereby screening the disgust and horror of dead flesh. Shelley also compared a meat diet to alcoholism, inquiring, "How many thousands have become murderers and robbers, bigots and domestic tyrants, dissolute and abandoned adventurers, from the use of fermented liquors?"<ref name="Shelley, Percy Bysshe 1813, pp 16"/> Shelley used comparative anatomy to show that the human digestive system resembles that of [[frugivore|frugivorous]] or plant-eating animals. He concluded that a person with compassion and empathy for animals, "rising from a meal of roots", would be able to maintain a healthy and balanced diet and lifestyle. Shelley presented examples of how a vegetarian diet resulted in longevity and an increased lifespan. The only threat of death will be that of natural, old age.<ref name="Shelley, Percy Bysshe 1813, pp. 1" /> The two rules he prescribes for a natural diet are to never eat anything that was alive and to drink only distilled water.

'''Presidential elections''' were held in [[Afghanistan]] on 20 August 2009.<ref name=mixed/> The election resulted in victory for incumbent [[Hamid Karzai]], who won 49.67% of the vote, while his main rival [[Abdullah Abdullah]] finished second with 30.59% of the vote.
The election was characterized by lack of security, low voter turnout and low awareness of the people about the election and election process and widespread ballot stuffing, intimidation, and other electoral fraud.<ref name=invalid>{{Cite web|last=McDonald |first=Charlotte |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i3xqZSi2U_mgENDm3TK0-yqI7I_g |title=Afghan commission orders first ballots invalidated |date=2009-09-10 |accessdate=2010-04-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100413122433/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i3xqZSi2U_mgENDm3TK0-yqI7I_g| archivedate=April 13, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=scrapped>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/03/world/asia/03afghan.html?_r=1&hp Karzai Gets New Term as Afghan Runoff is Scrapped], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref name=messy>{{Cite news|last=Dixon |first=Robyn |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-fg-obama-karzai3-2009nov03,0,963693.story |title=Obama calls Afghan election 'messy' but upholds its final outcome |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091105050208/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-fg-obama-karzai3-2009nov03%2C0%2C963693.story |archivedate=November 5, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> A [[#November 7 run-off election|second round run-off vote]], announced under heavy U.S. and ally pressure, was originally scheduled for 7 November 2009, but [[#Run-off cancelled and winner declared|it was cancelled]] after Abdullah refused to participate, and [[Hamid Karzai]] was declared [[President of Afghanistan]] for another 5-year term.<ref name=scrapped/><ref name=messy/>
The election was the second under the present [[constitution of Afghanistan]] and was held on the same day as elections for 34 [[Provinces of Afghanistan|provincial council]] seats. The [[Taliban]] called for a boycott of the election, describing it as a "''program of the crusaders''" and "''this American process''".<ref name=ordinary>{{Cite web|first=Abdulhadi |last=Hairan |title=Afghanistan: 'Ordinary people want change' |url=http://www.guardianweekly.co.uk/?page=editorial&id=1199&catID=1 |publisher=[[The Guardian Weekly]] |date=2009-08-11 |accessdate=2009-08-18}}</ref><ref name=killed26/><ref name=farce>{{Cite web|last=Margolis |first=Eric |url=http://www.torontosun.com/comment/columnists/eric_margolis/2009/08/16/10476066-sun.html |title=Afghan elections will be a farce |website=Toronto Sun |date=2009-08-16 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
==Election date== Under the [[Constitution of Afghanistan|2004 constitution]], elections should have been held no later than 60 days before the end of President Karzai's term in July 2009. The Independent Election Commission (IEC) originally recommended that the poll be held at the same time as the 2010 parliamentary balloting to save costs. However, politicians in the country were unable to agree to the details.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120904050930/http://www.afghanconflictmonitor.org/2008/04/afghanistan-to.html Afghanistan To Hold Separate Presidential, Parliamentary Elections], ''[[The Canadian Press]]'', 2008-04-09</ref> Concerns about accessibility to mountainous areas in spring 2009 and the ability of getting adequate people and materials in place by then led the IEC to announce the elections would be delayed to August 2009.
The opposition accused Karzai of attempting to extend his power past his term. In February 2009, President Hamid Karzai called on the Independent Election Committee to hold the election according to the country's constitution,<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7916607.stm|work=BBC News |title=Afghan president urges April poll|date=2009-02-28|accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.voanews.com/uspolicy/2009-03-09-voa7.cfm |title=Afghanistan's Election Dilemma |publisher=[[Voice of America]] |date=2009-03-09 |accessdate=2009-03-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331141358/http://www.voanews.com/uspolicy/2009-03-09-voa7.cfm |archivedate=March 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/03/02/karzai_leave/ |title=Karzai won't leave: Afghan President Hamid Karzai discovered the importance of adhering to his country's constitution at an awfully convenient political moment |first=Matthias |last=Gebauer |author2=Shoib Najafizada |website=[[Salon.com|Salon]]/[[Der Spiegel]] |date=2009-03-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hvWEqwq3CrRvaQCmt21MfoYhjZJQD960QBF80 |accessdate=January 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205115208/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hvWEqwq3CrRvaQCmt21MfoYhjZJQD960QBF80 |archivedate=February 5, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Afghanistan vote date announced |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7857451.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-01-29 |accessdate=2009-01-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090129214149/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7857451.stm| archivedate=January 29, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> thereby forcing the IEC to reiterate the August date, and silencing critics, who feared a leadership vacuum between May and August.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/30/world/asia/30afghan.html "Afghan Presidential Election Delayed"], ''The New York Times''</ref> Some potential Afghan opponents complained Karzai's move was an attempt to clear the field of challengers, most of whom would not be ready to campaign for the 2009 election.<ref>{{Cite news|first=Matthew |last=Rosenberg |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123590141734903121?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=U.S., Afghans Criticize Call for Early Elections |work=Wall Street Journal |date=2009-03-02 |accessdate=2009-08-18}}</ref> After the IEC and the international community rejected Karzai's decree, Karzai accepted the date of August 20, 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7929980.stm |title=Karzai agrees to delay elections |publisher=BBC |date=2009-03-07 |accessdate=2009-08-18}}</ref> The Supreme Court of Afghanistan announced in March 2009 that Karzai's term would be extended until a new leader had been elected.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090329/ap_on_re_as/as_afghanistan;_ylt=AnO_603G8IR_xKeyRUJ5OyFw24cA ]{{Dead link|date=April 2010}}</ref> His opponents called the decision unconstitutional and unacceptable, pointing out that it put Karzai in a position to exploit the office to secure his electoral victory.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Najibullah |first=Farangis |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Karzais_Opponents_Slam_Supreme_Court_Ruling_As_Unconstitutional_/1564465.html |title=Karzai's Opponents Slam Supreme Court Ruling As 'Unconstitutional' |publisher=Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty |date=2009-03-30 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
The election date of August 20, 2009 was one day after the Afghan anniversary of the formal end of Britain's [[Third Anglo-Afghan War|third attempt]] to conquer Afghanistan ninety years ago in 1919.<ref name=afraud/>
==Candidates== [[File:Afghan presidential election, 2009 poster 2.jpg|thumb|Election billboards showing two of the candidates at [[Kandahar]].]] {{See also|List of candidates in the Afghan presidential election, 2009}}
Forty-four candidates had registered for the presidential election when the Independent Election Commission of Afghanistan (IEC) announced its official preliminary list of registered candidates on May 17, 2009. Three candidates withdrew from the race before the election took place, having thrown their support behind one of the top two contenders. Each presidential candidate ran with two vice-presidential candidates.<ref name=ordinary/><ref>[http://www.ifes.org/publication/a05e4a3ba20a60b82a650a1fa9e18ecf/Election_Kit_Afghanistan.pdf Afghanistan2009 Presidential and Provincial Council Elections Kit] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616213130/http://www.ifes.org/publication/a05e4a3ba20a60b82a650a1fa9e18ecf/Election_Kit_Afghanistan.pdf |date=June 16, 2011 }}, [[International Foundation for Electoral Systems]].</ref><ref>http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6659282.html</ref>
Karzai filed his candidacy on May 4, 2009; he retained incumbent second Vice President [[Karim Khalili]], who is from the [[Hazara people|Hazara]] ethnic group but exchanged the first Vice President [[Ahmad Zia Massood]] for [[Mohammad Qasim Fahim]], a [[Tajik people|Tajik]] former warlord blamed by human rights groups for mass civilian deaths during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghan Civil War]].<ref>[http://washingtontimes.com/news/2009/may/08/karzai-jockeys-to-stay-in-power/ Afghan Karzai likely to win reelection], ''[[Washington Times]]'', 2009-05-08</ref>
The [[United National Front (Afghanistan)|United National Front]] announced on April 16, 2009 that they would nominate former foreign minister Dr. [[Abdullah Abdullah (politician)|Abdullah Abdullah]] as their presidential candidate. Abdullah was foreign minister of the [[United Islamic Front for the Salvation of Afghanistan|Northern Alliance]] from 1998 onwards, and was a dominant figure in the [[United Islamic Front for the Salvation of Afghanistan|Alliance]]. He was appointed foreign minister in the interim government that was installed after the U.S. invasion.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/afghan-opposition-picks-candidate-20090416-a8j5.html |title=Afghan opposition picks candidate |publisher=News.smh.com.au |date=2009-04-16 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=FACTBOX/><ref name=newopt>{{Cite web|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/Opinion/1140249.html |title=Afghan election only shows a new option is needed |website=The Chronicle Herald |date=2010-04-07|accessdate=2010-04-07}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name=wizard>{{Cite web|author= |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/KI01Df02.html |title=Wizards and wives drive Afghan election |website=Asia Times |date=2009-09-01 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
The first person to have declared his intention to run, Dr. [[Ramazan Bashardost]] formally registered for the presidential election on May 7, 2009, with vice-presidential candidates Mr. Mohammad Mosa Barekzai, a professor at the Kabul Agricultural Institute and Ms. Afifa Maroof, a member of the Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission, and with a dove, a symbol of peace and liberty, as their campaign symbol. Bashardost openly criticized the government and accused ministers of corruption. While serving as the planning minister, he was critical of foreign organizations in Afghanistan eating up aid money meant for the Afghan people and later resigned under government and foreign pressure.<ref name=FACTBOX>A [https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSSP345133 FACTBOX - Possible Afghan presidential candidates]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kabulpress.org/my/spip.php?article3456 |title=Dr. Ramazan Bashardost officially enters presidential campaign |publisher=Kabulpress.org |date=2009-05-07 |accessdate=2010-04-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100401183226/http://kabulpress.org/my/spip.php?article3456| archivedate=April 1, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=MrClean>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rfi.fr/actuen/articles/116/article_4803.asp |title=Afghan Mr Clean takes on Karzai ... and everyone else |publisher=Rfi.fr |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
Dr. [[Ashraf Ghani]], a senior fellow in foreign policy at the [[Brookings Institution]] in Washington D.C., and former finance minister, UN special advisor, and [[World Bank]] analyst, registered as a presidential candidate on May 7, 2009. At a time when many Afghans would have preferred to lessen the appearance of ties to the U.S. government, he had the distinction of hiring Clinton-campaign chief strategist [[James Carville]] as his campaign advisor. His close ties to Washington placed him among those that Afghans considered to be "''Zana-e-Bush''", literally "Bush's wives". Ashraf Ghani was also reported as the candidate most favoured by the U.S. for appointment to a "chief executive officer" position that the U.S. intended to insert regardless of the winner of the election.{{Clarify|date=July 2017}}<ref name=farce/><ref name=FACTBOX/><ref name=wizard/><ref name=wizard/><ref name=poolsclose/><ref name=obama>{{Cite news|author=Ewen MacAskill |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/19/obama-chief-executive-afghanistan |title=Obama administration to continue push for chief executive in Afghanistan |work=Guardian |location=UK |date= 2009-08-19|accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=JC>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=107006724 |title=James Carville Joins The Afghan Campaign Trail |publisher=Npr.org |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=squand>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2009/08/20/2009-08-20_why_im_rooting_against_h.html |title=Afghanistan's president has squandered the people's trust |work=Daily News |date=2009-08-20 |accessdate=2010-04-07 | location=New York | first=Michael | last=Weiss}}</ref>
[[Mirwais Yasini]], the First Deputy Speaker of the Afghan [[House of the People (Afghanistan)|House of the People]] joined the race in March 2009. He was previously a member of the Emergency [[Loya Jirga]] convened in 2002, served as deputy of the [[Loya Jirga]], and director of counter narcotics and deputy minister of counter narcotics.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.pajhwokelections.af/contender_biography.php?id=6 |title=Contender Biographies – Mir Wais Yasini's Biography |publisher=Pajhwokelections.af |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706070811/http://www.pajhwokelections.af/contender_biography.php?id=6 |archivedate=July 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Shahla Atta]], a liberal female MP and war widow also stood, pledging to revive the modernizing policies of 1973–1978 president [[Mohammad Daoud Khan]].<ref name=Star>[https://www.thestar.com/article/616932 "Stuck between Karzai, hard place"], ''[[Toronto Star]]'', 2009-04-11</ref>
Other presidential contenders included the leader of the Justice and Development Party of Afghanistan Zabihullah Ghazi Nuristani; former attorney general [[Abdul Jabbar Sabit]]; former defence minister [[Shah Nawaz Tanai]]; [[Uzbek people|Uzbek]] leader Akbar Bai; economy expert and current senior minister [[Hedayat Arsala]]; economist [[Mohammad Hashem Taufiqui]]; Sarwar Ahmedzai, a former member of the 2002 Afghan Loya Jirga who authored a 2009 country report for U.S. officials formulating a new U.S. strategy for Afghanistan; and others.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.pajhwokelections.af/contender_biography.php?id=17 |title=Zabihullah Ghazi Nuristani's Biography |publisher=Pajhwokelections.af |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706070800/http://www.pajhwokelections.af/contender_biography.php?id=17 |archivedate=July 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author= |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6651526.html |title=Ex-Afghan Attorney General sings up for presidential elections |website=People's Daily |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pajhwokelections.af/contender_biography.php?id=3 |title=Contender Biographies – Sarwar Ahmedzai's Biography |publisher=Pajhwokelections.af |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706070805/http://www.pajhwokelections.af/contender_biography.php?id=3 |archivedate=July 6, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>
Along with the presidential candidates, were 3197 candidates for 420 provincial council positions. A Provincial Council in each of Afghanistan's 34 provinces advises and works with the provincial administration, headed by a Governor that is appointed by the President.<ref name=mixed/><ref>{{Cite web|author=NET LINKS |url=http://www.afghanelections.org/index.php?page=en_Provincial+Council |title=UNDP/ELECT - Provincial Council Elections |publisher=Afghanelections.org |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821135435/http://www.afghanelections.org/index.php?page=en_Provincial%2BCouncil |archivedate=August 21, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
===Prominent involvement of warlords=== According to human rights groups, at least 70 candidates with links to "illegal armed groups" were on the ballot list in the election.<ref name=breath/>
While the electoral law disallowed candidates with links to "illegal armed groups", and the [[#Systemic conflicts of interest|Karzai-appointed]] Independent Election Commission had barred 56 other candidates that it identified as being commanders or members of illegal militias, many of the bigger [[warlord]]s, including current parliamentarians and provincial council members elected in 2004 and 2005, simply bypassed this by registering their militias as [[private military company|private security companies]] or by having the right political connections.<ref name=breath/><ref name=canada>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=azZCwLShznhc |title=Afghan Election's Legitimacy May Hang on Canadian's Judgment |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2009-08-23 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=clouds/><ref name=US2/>
Both of Hamid Karzai's vice-presidential candidates and many of his key allies in the election are alleged to have committed widespread human rights violations and [[war crime]]s. [[Human Rights Watch]] has called for Vice President [[Karim Khalili]] and key ally, former army chief of staff General [[Abdul Rashid Dostum]], to face trial before a special court for alleged war crimes. Khalili is alleged to have been responsible in the killing of thousands of innocent people.<ref name=farce/><ref name=US2>{{Cite web|author=Jooneed Khan |url=http://www.dominionpaper.ca/articles/1148 |title=The US has Returned Fundamentalism to Afghanistan |publisher=Dominionpaper.ca |date=2007-05-06 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=former>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/23/AR2007022300251_pf.html |title=Former Mujahedeen Stage Rally in Kabul |work=The Washington Post |date=2007-02-23 |accessdate=2010-04-07|first=Amir|last=Shah}}</ref><ref name=boost>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6799717.ece Afghan warlord General Dostum returns to boost Karzai’s campaign]</ref><ref name=flames>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afghanwomensmission.org/awmnews/index.php?articleID=65 |title=Five Years Later, Afghanistan Still in Flames |publisher=Afghanwomensmission.org |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230224159/http://www.afghanwomensmission.org/awmnews/index.php?articleID=65 |archivedate=December 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=Malalai>{{Cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=07/06/19/1433256 |title="The Bravest Woman in Afghanistan": Malalai Joya Speaks Out Against the Warlord-Controlled Afghan Government & U.S. Military Presence |publisher=Democracynow.org |accessdate=2010-04-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114145621/http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=07%2F06%2F19%2F1433256 |archivedate=November 14, 2007 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=strange>{{Cite web|url=http://www.comw.org/pda/0201strangevic.html#1.2 |title=Strange Victory: A critical appraisal of Operation Enduring Freedom and the Afghanistan war |publisher=Comw.org |accessdate=2010-04-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100505064107/http://www.comw.org/pda/0201strangevic.html| archivedate=May 5, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=HR>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/03/26/human-rights-watch-letter-president-barack-obama-afghanistan |title=Human Rights Watch letter to President Obama on Afghanistan |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=2009-03-26 |accessdate=2010-04-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100414114323/http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2009/03/26/human-rights-watch-letter-president-barack-obama-afghanistan| archivedate=April 14, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Karzai's other vice-presidential candidate and former senior security advisor [[Mohammad Qasim Fahim]], along with Karzai backer and former energy minister [[Ismail Khan]], have also been listed by the human rights group as among the "worst perpetrators." Better known as Marshal Fahim, the vice-presidential candidate is accused of having been a former Communist secret police chief, murdering prisoners of war during the 1990s, running private armed militias, and involvement in kidnapping and other crimes after 2001. Fahim, a key U.S. ally in the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|U.S. invasion of Afghanistan]], had also previously served as Karzai's First Vice President and Minister of Defense, having been appointed to those positions in the interim and transitional governments installed after the 2001 invasion. Karzai is also being advised by [[Abdul Rasul Sayyaf]], who is said to have first invited [[Osama bin Laden]] to Afghanistan and has lobbied for an amnesty for warlords.<ref name=farce/><ref name=newopt/><ref name=US2/><ref name=former/><ref name=boost/><ref name=flames/><ref name=Malalai/><ref name=strange/><ref name=HR/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parliament.af/pme/showdoc.aspx?Id=12 |title=Parliament of Afghanistan |publisher=Parliament.af |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113173536/http://www.parliament.af/pme/showdoc.aspx?Id=12 |archivedate=November 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=accused>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/27/world/asia/27kabul.html "Accused of Drug Ties, Afghan Official Worries U.S."]. ''The New York Times''</ref>
Most prominently covered was the dramatic return, three days before the election, of General [[Abdul Rashid Dostum]] from exile in Turkey as part of a deal to help bring President Karzai to victory. After allegedly [[Abdul Rashid Dostum#Akbar Bai kidnapping|kidnapping and beating up a political rival]], he was removed as Karzai's army chief of staff in late 2008 and disappeared into exile in Turkey. A key U.S. ally during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|U.S. invasion of Afghanistan]], General Dostum is arguably the most notorious of Afghanistan's warlords, accused of massive human rights abuses, including the [[Dasht-i-Leili massacre]] of up to 2,000 Taliban who were suffocated in cargo containers in late 2001. He is also alleged to have crushed one of his own soldiers to death by tying him to the tracks of a tank.<ref name=wizard/><ref name=US2/><ref name=boost/><ref name=Malalai/><ref name=strange/>
Many Afghans hate these powerbrokers in the Afghan government, angered that they evaded accountability for their human rights abuses in the nineties and regained power and land through private militias funded by the millions of dollars they were paid by the [[CIA]] in the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|2001 U.S. invasion]].<ref name=US2/><ref name=flames/><ref name=Malalai/><ref name=accused/><ref name=US>{{Cite web|last=Landay |first=Jonathan S. |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/world/story/1192161.html |title=Afghan election fraught with political risk for U.S |website=Miami Herald |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091007020740/http://www.miamiherald.com/news/world/story/1192161.html |archivedate=October 7, 2009 }}</ref>
Analysts have suggested that part of Karzai's strategy was to make deals with warlord allies to deliver large blocs of votes in return for key positions and influence in his new government or other significant promises.<ref name=newopt/><ref name=wizard/><ref name=boost/><ref name=US/><ref name=qtime/><ref name=scheme/><ref name=US3/>
In the immediate aftermath of the election, analysts and diplomats suggested that Karzai's alliances with [[strongman (politics)|strongmen]] like General Dostum had paid off, delivering him large numbers of votes in the north. Fahim delivered Tajik votes for Karzai, Khalili brought Hazara support, and Dostum delivered Uzbek votes.<ref name=newopt/><ref name=wizard/><ref name=US3/><ref name=twoclaim/><ref name=insult/><ref name=pulls/>
===Involvement of drug traffickers=== Karzai's vice-presidential candidate, Marshal [[Muhammad Qasim Fahim]], is also alleged to have long ties to drug trafficking, according to CIA reports from as early as 2002.<ref name=accused/>
A crucial U.S. ally as the military commander of the [[United Islamic Front for the Salvation of Afghanistan|Northern Alliance]], he worked closely with the [[CIA]] in the 2001 U.S. invasion of Afghanistan and was rewarded with millions of dollars in cash. He was then appointed First Vice President and Minister of Defense in the interim and transitional governments installed after the invasion, handling more millions of dollars sent by the U.S. in military aid to raise and arm a new Afghan army. CIA intelligence reports in 2002 showed that Fahim had a history of narcotics trafficking before the U.S. invasion, and that he was still actively involved after being installed as defense minister, trafficking heroin via cargo plane flights north through Russia, with aides in the Afghan Defense Ministry also involved.<ref name=accused/>
Hamid Karzai's election campaign manager for the south, and half-brother, [[Ahmed Wali Karzai]] – himself a candidate for re-election as the head of the Kandahar provincial council – has also long been alleged to have prominent drug trafficking ties, and was thought to control a significant proportion of Afghan heroin production. Numerous reports link him to the Afghan drug trade, according to officials from the White House, the [[State Department]] and the United States Embassy in Afghanistan. Officials at the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] (DEA) and the Office of the [[Director of National Intelligence]] have alleged that the [[White House]] favored a hands-off approach with Ahmed Wali Karzai because of his political position. Only a week before the election he denied a report from German news magazine [[Stern (magazine)|Stern]] that said that British special forces had found several tons of [[opium]] on his land. He claimed that this was being done just before the election to hurt Hamid Karzai's chance of re-election.<ref name=link>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/05/world/asia/05afghan.html "Reports Link Karzai’s Brother to Afghanistan Heroin Trade"], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=Peter Graff |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/GCA-Afghanistan-Pakistan/idUSTRE57C2Z220090813 |title=Afghan president's brother denies drugs link |agency=Reuters |date=2009-08-13 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=narco>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/27/magazine/27AFGHAN-t.html Is "Afghanistan a Narco-State?"], ''The New York Times''</ref>
According to current and former U.S. officials, Ahmed Wali Karzai was also being paid by [[CIA]], and had been for the past eight years. The New York Times [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/28/world/asia/28intel.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all reported] on October 27, 2009, stating: "''The C.I.A.’s practices also suggest that the United States is not doing everything in its power to stamp out the lucrative Afghan drug trade.''" Also alleged to have orchestrated much of the [[#Election fraud|fraud]] in favour of his brother in the presidential election, Ahmed Wali Karzai was himself re-elected to the Kandahar provincial council in the August 20 vote.<ref name=CIA>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/28/world/asia/28intel.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all "Brother of Afghan Leader Said to Be Paid by C.I.A."], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iec.org.af/results/Provincial/ElectedP28.html |title=IEC Final Uncertified Provincial Council Results 27-Oct-09 2:00 PM |publisher=Iec.org.af |accessdate=2010-04-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407184620/http://www.iec.org.af/results/Provincial/ElectedP28.html |archivedate=April 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
==Campaign== The Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission (AIHRC), said insecurity had "severely limited freedom of movement and constrained freedom of expression for candidates".<ref name=AlJ/><ref name=willnot/> Security concerns prevented presidential candidates from campaigning in most of the provinces, and candidates running for provincial councils were under constant threat wherever they went.<ref name=ordinary/> Widespread cultural opposition to women in public life, further compounded by the lack of security, made campaigning by women candidates very difficult or impossible in many parts of the country, according to EU observers.<ref name=intimid/> [[File:Afghan presidential election, 2009 poster 4.jpg|thumb|Election billboard for [[Hamid Karzai]] in the outskirt of Kandahar City.]]
A UN election monitoring report said in early August that there was mounting evidence that the government was using state resources to favour Karzai. An election commission report in July noted that state-run [[Radio Television Afghanistan]] had dedicated 71% of prime-time news coverage to the president.<ref name=willnot/><ref name=key/>
Issues at the forefront in the election campaign were the insurgency and [[#Lack of security|lack of security]], the conduct of foreign troops in Afghanistan and [[Civilian casualties of the War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|civilian casualties]], [[#Election fraud|corruption]], and [[#Bribes being offered|poverty]]. Topics concerning women's rights were virtually never featured in news coverage of the electoral campaign, and women received almost no coverage in news reporting during the election, according to a European Union observation mission report.<ref name=ordinary/><ref name=intimid/><ref name=key>{{Cite web|url=http://tolo.tv/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=261&Itemid=42 |title=Foreign troops a key issue in Afghan presidential |publisher=Tolo.tv |date=2009-07-28 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
Mr. Karzai announced that he would invite the Taliban to a [[Loya Jirga]] (a grand tribal council) to try to restart stalled peace talks. A May pre-election poll reported that over two-thirds, 68%, of Afghans thought their government should hold talks and reconcile with the Taliban, and 18% did not know or refused to answer. Only 14% did not support government talks and reconciliation with the Taliban. Karzai also said the country was growing in stature and would be able to prevent "foreigners" from jailing Afghans, referring to the foreign military forces operating in their country.<ref name=ordinary/><ref name=willnot/><ref name=IRI/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/m/story.html?id=1894765 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110104045050/http://www.nationalpost.com/m/story.html?id=1894765 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-01-04 |title=Candidates take campaigns across Afghanistan |website=National Post |location=Canada |date=2009-08-14 |accessdate=2010-04-07 }}</ref>
According to Ramazan Bashardost, the insurgency was motivated by the presence of foreign military forces in their country, by the presence of warlords and human rights abusers in the Western-backed regime, by the corruption in that government, and by poverty. Bashardost vowed that he would not allow foreign troops to stay in Afghanistan if elected.<ref name=MrClean/><ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6797093.ece Abdullah Abdullah throws down election gauntlet to President Karzai]</ref>
[[Abdul Salam Rocketi]], a former [[Mujahideen]] "[[freedom fighter]]" – whose name came from using rocket-propelled grenades to shoot down Soviet helicopters – and former Taliban commander, said he would announce an amnesty for all the [[insurgents]] if he won the election.<ref name=ordinary/><ref>{{Cite web|author= |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=111349105 |title=Candidates' Stories Reflect Afghanistan's Struggle |publisher=Npr.org |date=2009-07-30 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
The Election Commission accredited 160,000 observers for the election. The Afghan Free and Fair Elections Foundation, the largest local monitoring group, said that it would have observers at 70 per cent of polling stations but couldn't observe the remainder because of security concerns.<ref name=buy/>
===Debates=== Two candidate debates took place before the August 20 election. The first debate was held on July 23 and was broadcast on [[Tolo TV]]. It was supposed to feature Karzai, Abdullah, and Ghani, though Karzai later declined to take part, with his campaign blaming Tolo TV for being biased against him.<ref>{{Cite news|first=Carlotta |last=Gall |author2=Wafa, Abdul Waheed |title=Afghanistan’s Leader Skips an Election Debate, Claiming Bias |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/24/world/asia/24karzai.html |work=The New York Times |date=2009-07-23 |accessdate=2009-08-18}}</ref> A second debate took place on August 16 on [[RTA TV]] (the state broadcaster) and [[Radio Free Afghanistan]]<ref>{{Cite news|first=Abubakar |last=Siddique |title=In Landmark Debate, Afghan Presidential Contenders Challenge Karzai |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/In_Landmark_Debate_Afghan_Presidential_Contenders_Challenge_Karzai_On_Corruption_Warlords/1800957.html |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=2009-08-16 |accessdate=2009-08-18| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090820072029/http://www.rferl.org/content/In_Landmark_Debate_Afghan_Presidential_Contenders_Challenge_Karzai_On_Corruption_Warlords/1800957.html| archivedate=August 20, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> involving Karzai, Ghani, and Bashardost, with Abdullah not participating.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Karzai, rivals debate as Afghan elections near |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/08/16/afghanistan.elections/index.html |publisher=CNN |date=2009-08-16 |accessdate=2009-08-18}}</ref>
===Pre-election polls=== The pre-election polls, funded by the U.S. government and conducted by Washington D.C.-based organizations, found Hamid Karzai leading his nearest rival, Abdullah Abdullah, by a wide margin, but suggested that he would not have the 50% support required to win the August 20 election outright, raising the prospect of a run off election in October.<ref name=AlJ>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2009/08/200981194629468195.html Polls: Karzai could face run-off], ''[[Al Jazeera]]'', 2009-08-11</ref><ref name=willnot>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/6010602/Hamid-Karzai-will-not-win-Afghan-election-outright.html Hamid Karzai 'will not' win Afghan election outright], ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 2009-08-11</ref><ref>[http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-14-voa20.cfm New Poll Shows Afghan President Leading Race for a Second Term] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090816160138/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-14-voa20.cfm |date=August 16, 2009 }}, ''[[Voice of America]]'', 2008-08-14</ref><ref>[http://www.iri.org/mena/afghanistan/pdfs/2009%20August%2014%20Survey%20of%20Afghan%20Public%20Opinion%20July%2016-26,%202009.pdf Afghanistan Public Opinion Survey:July 16–26, 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090824005330/http://www.iri.org/mena/afghanistan/pdfs/2009%20August%2014%20Survey%20of%20Afghan%20Public%20Opinion%20July%2016-26%2C%202009.pdf |date=August 24, 2009 }}, ''[[International Republican Institute]]'', 2008-08-14</ref>

The administering of public opinion polls for the 2009 presidential election was beset by numerous difficulties because of the lack of security, harsh geography, and lack of accurate demographic data, but analysts hoped that with improved sampling techniques the pre-election polls would be more predictive of [[#Post-election vote count and investigations|the outcome]] than they were in 2004.<ref>{{Cite news|first=Brian |last=Palmer |title=How Accurate Is Pre-Election Polling in Afghanistan? |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2225508/ |publisher=Slate |date=2009-08-17 |accessdate=2009-08-18| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090823115456/http://www.slate.com/id/2225508/| archivedate=August 23, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Lack of security== Despite the surge of 30 thousand additional foreign military troops into Afghanistan in the three to four months leading up to the elections, and major military operations in the weeks and days ahead of the election, 12 out of Afghanistan's 34 provinces remained classified as "high risk" by the Afghan Ministry of Interior – meaning limited or no government presence – casting into doubt the ability of over one-third of the country to participate in the elections.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6036318.ece Extra Nato troops for Afghan elections]</ref><ref name=hires/><ref name=USbrit>{{Cite web |url=http://story.heraldglobe.com/index.php/ct/9/cid/15665b944045da4a/id/533627/cs/1/ |title=US, British soldiers killed in attacks in Afghanistan |publisher=Story.heraldglobe.com |date=2009-08-21 |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711163420/http://story.heraldglobe.com/index.php/ct/9/cid/15665b944045da4a/id/533627/cs/1/ |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=breath>{{Cite news|author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/free-and-fair-elections-in-afghanistan-dont-hold-your-breath/article1255051/ |title=Free and fair elections in Afghanistan? Don't hold your breath |work=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=2010-04-07 |location=Toronto, Canada|date=2009-08-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100228161827/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/free-and-fair-elections-in-afghanistan-dont-hold-your-breath/article1255051/| archivedate=February 28, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[File:Aghanistan 2009 -- 'Go vote!'.jpg|thumb|'Go vote!' billboard prominently depicting armed security forces at polling stations.]]
A week and a half before the election, the Afghan government announced that it had hired 10,000 tribesmen to provide additional security for the election in almost two-thirds of Afghanistan's provinces. The men were being paid $160 a month, would be non-uniformed, and would use their own guns to secure polling stations in 21 out of Afghanistan's 34 provinces.<ref name=willnot/><ref name=hires>[http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/breakingnews/Afghanistan-hires-10_000-tribesmen-for-security-at-polling-stations-in-presidential-election-52954712.html Afghanistan hires 10,000 tribesmen for security at polling stations in presidential election]</ref>
ISAF officials stated two days before the election that the 60,000-troop ISAF military force in Afghanistan would halt all offensive operations on polling day in order to help Afghan forces maintain security for the presidential election. The order to halt operations and divert forces to help security followed a similar order issued to Afghan forces by Afghan President Hamid Karzai.<ref name=halted>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2009/08/18/afghanistan-presidential-election-nato471.html |title=Offensives halted for Afghan election |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2009-08-18 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8185222.stm |title=Outrage over Afghan child deaths |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-08-05 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
Because of the lack of security, the full list of polling centers was only announced on the actual polling day.<ref name=shut/>
A day before the election, hundreds of polling stations were ordered closed in parts of the country where military and police forces fear to go and would not be able to provide protection for election monitors. It had previously been estimated that as many as 700 out of 7,000 polling stations across the country would not open because of the widespread insecurity.<ref name=shut/><ref name=kandahar>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/16/afghanistan-hamid-karzai-elections Karzai counts on tribal vote to win Kandahar] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819133847/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/aug/16/afghanistan-hamid-karzai-elections |date=August 19, 2009 }}</ref> On election day, the Afghan election commission reported that only 6,200 polling stations had operated.<ref name=hires/><ref name=knockout>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/karzai-quick-to-claim-knockout-victory-20090821-etu8.html |title=Karzai quick to claim knockout victory |work=The Age |date=2009-08-22 |accessdate=2010-04-07 | location=Melbourne, Australia | first1=James | last1=Rupert}}</ref>
In [[Kandahar province]], the mayor of [[Kandahar]] city, Ghulam Haider Hamidi, said that he would not go vote. "For the last three years the security is getting worse, day by day," Hamidi stated. "Even a child understands that the election day is not safe." His daughter, [[Rangina Hamidi]], a prominent women's advocate, said that it was not worth the risk and that she would not vote either:
<blockquote> "''My message to the women of Kandahar is this: don't go vote and put yourselves at risk for nothing.''"<ref name=mars>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gzgWRF7lMjPe680x3Iu6sZF3t0VQ Violence mars last day of Afghanistan's presidential election campaign]{{Dead link|date=April 2010}}</ref> </blockquote>
===Attacks ahead of the vote=== Already in the month preceding the election day, there was a rise in violent incidents, all over Afghanistan, including a [[suicide bomber]] attack on the [[India]]n embassy in Kabul on July 7.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/kabul-suicide-bomber-kills-41-in-worst-attack-since-fall-of-taliban-862060.html |title=Kabul suicide bomber kills 41 in worst attack since fall of Taliban - Suspicion falls on Pakistani intelligence after embassy blast |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=2008-07-08 |accessdate=2010-04-07|first1=Miles|last1=Amoore|first2=Kim|last2=Sengupta}}</ref> An ISAF spokesperson stated two days before the election that insurgent attacks had averaged 32 per day in the last 10 days, but had spiked up to 48 attacks per day within the last four days.<ref name=insurgent>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2009/08/18/afghanistan-presidential-election-nato471.html |title=Insurgent attacks spike in run-up to Afghan vote |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2009-08-18 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref> Among the major attacks reported:
*On August 15, 2009, five days before the election, a suicide car bomb struck NATO's headquarters at the core of Kabul's most fortified district, in the equivalent of Baghdad's [[Green Zone]]. The massive blast that shook the city left seven people dead and 91 wounded, including several foreign soldiers, four Afghan soldiers, and a member of parliament. The attack, inside several rings of security around the fortified embassies and government buildings by the presidential palace, was confirmed by a Taliban spokesperson to have had as targets the NATO military headquarters (HQ ISAF) and the U.S. embassy less than 150 meters away, and to have been part of a campaign to disrupt the elections.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Fawad Muslim |url=http://www.afghanistannewscenter.com/news/2009/august/aug162009.html#11 |title=Afghanistan News August 16, 2009 |publisher=Afghanistannewscenter.com |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/crossroads-afghanistan/story/2009/08/15/kabul-attack.html |title=Canadian among injured in Kabul car bombing |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=2009-08-15 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref> *On August 18, 2009, two days before the vote, rocket attacks or mortar rounds struck near the presidential palace in Kabul, and a suicide car bomb attack on a NATO convoy heading to a British military base killed nine people and wounded around 50. One NATO soldier was killed and two others wounded. Two UN staff members were killed, and a third was wounded. About 12 vehicles were destroyed and several surrounding buildings were damaged by the blast. A suicide bomb attack at the gates of an Afghan army base in the province of [[Uruzgan]] also killed three Afghan soldiers and two civilians.<ref name=halted/><ref name=shut/><ref>{{Cite news|author= |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/taliban-steps-up-election-terror-campaign-1774047.html |title=Taliban steps up election terror campaign - Suicide attack on Nato convoy kills 10 as violence sweeps Afghanistan before poll |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref> *On August 19, 2009, gunmen seized control of a bank in downtown Kabul one day before the Afghan election. The bold raid was the third major attack in Kabul in five days, shattering the capital city's relative calm since the last major attacks there in February. Police reported that three fighters and three policemen were killed in the four-hour-long siege.<ref name=gunmen>[https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2009/08/19/world/international-us-afghanistan.html "Gunmen In Bloody Kabul Siege on Eve Of Afghan Election"], ''The New York Times''</ref>
===Media blackout imposed=== In decrees issued two days before the presidential election, the Afghan government imposed censorship for election day, barring news organizations from reporting any information about violence between 6 a.m. and 8 p.m. out of concern that reports of violence could reduce voter turnout and damage chances of staging a successful election. Low turnout could undermine the credibility of the election – and could also hurt Karzai's results in the election if not enough ethnic [[Pashtun people]], who form his base of support, turned out for the vote in the insurgent-dominated south of Afghanistan.<ref name=bans>{{Cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/southAsiaNews/idINIndia-41825520090818 |title=Afghanistan bans reporting of attacks during vote |publisher=In.reuters.com |date=2009-08-18 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/19/world/asia/19afghan.html?em "Afghanistan Imposes Censorship on Election Day"], ''The New York Times''</ref>
On the eve of the election, police at the Kabul bank beat journalists and bystanders with rifle butts to keep them away from the scene where the bloody siege had taken place.<ref name=gunmen/>
The head of the Afghan Independent Journalists' Association (AIJA) said that the government censorship decrees would not stop Afghan and foreign journalists from providing information to the public during the critical election period: "It shows the weakness of the government and we condemn such moves to deprive people from accessing news."<ref name=bans/>
Human Rights Watch also criticized the news censorship, stating: "An attempt to censor the reporting of violence is an unreasonable violation of press freedoms."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/449668/1/.html |title=Afghanistan calls for media blackout on polling day |publisher=Channelnewsasia.com |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
The Free and Fair Election Foundation of Afghanistan called the Afghan government's limitation of media freedom on election day "a violation of democratic principles".<ref name=FEFA/>
===Election day violence=== {{quote|text="''This was one of the most violent days witnessed in Afghanistan in the last eight years.''"|sign=Rachel Reid, researcher for [[Human Rights Watch]] in Afghanistan<ref name=twoclaim/>}}
Afghan government officials reported that 73 incidents of violence had taken place in 15 provinces throughout the country during voting. That number of attacks represented a 50% spike over NATO figures for the [[#Attacks ahead of the vote|violence in the days]] leading up to the poll.<ref name=killed26/><ref name=poolsclose>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/21/world/asia/21afghan.html?bl=&ei=5087&en=dd1c0cc23ceed45e&ex=1250913600&pagewanted=all Turnout Seen as Uneven in Afghanistan as Polls Close], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref name=keepsv>{{Cite news|author1=Jon Boone |author2=Peter Beaumont |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/20/afghanistan-elections-taliban-attack-voters |title=Afghanistan poll legitimacy fears as Taliban violence keeps voters away |work=Guardian |location=UK |date= 2009-08-20|accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
The Afghan government also reported that at least 26 people were killed in the election day violence, including eight Afghan soldiers, nine police officers and nine civilians.<ref name=mixed>{{Cite web|last=Siddique |first=Abubakar |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Mixed_Turnout_Violence_Seen_On_Afghan_Election_Day_As_Vote_Count_Begins/1804215.html |title=Mixed Turnout, Violence Seen On Afghan Election Day, As Vote Count Begins |publisher=Rferl.org |date=2009-08-21 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=killed26/><ref name=tout>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanchronicle.com/articles/yb/134368158 |title=Attacks, Threats Appear to Push Down Afghan Voter Turnout |publisher=Americanchronicle.com |date=2007-05-14 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
The government figures were impossible to verify, however, because of the government-imposed ban against reporting any information on violence. Anecdotal evidence suggested that the number of election day attacks could actually be much higher than the government reports.<ref name=twoclaim/><ref name=keepsv/>
Another report since has placed the number of attacks on election day in Afghanistan at more than 130.<ref name=USbrit/> - Broken link in citation.
ISAF has since reported that more than 400 militant attacks occurred on election day – making it one of the most violent days in Afghanistan since 2001.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8221709.stm |title=More Afghan poll results expected |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-08-26 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref> By comparison, ISAF had stated two days before the election that insurgent attacks had averaged 32 per day in the previous 10 days.<ref name=insurgent/>
In one of the worst reported attacks, militants stormed the town of [[Baghlan]] in northern Afghanistan, forcing all polling stations there to be closed down, with fighting lasting for most of the day. The district police chief was among those killed.<ref name=tout/><ref name=amid>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/Afghanistan/article6803686.ece Violence forces polls to shut amid low Afghan turnout]</ref>
Rocket attacks, gun battles, and bomb blasts occurred across much of the country, closing scores of polling stations. The province of Kandahar alone was hit by 122 insurgent rockets. Rockets and mortars were launched into [[Kandahar]], the second largest city in the country, [[Lashkar Gah]], the capital of Helmand province, [[Tirin Kot]], the provincial capital of [[Uruzgan]], as well as other cities.<ref name=FEFA/><ref name=keepsv/><ref name=tout/><ref name=amid/>
In an unconfirmed report, militants hanged two people in Kandahar because their index fingers were marked with indelible ink, showing that they had participated in the election that militants consider a tool of foreign occupation.<ref name=farce/><ref name=amid/> Before the elections militants had threatened to hack off the fingers seen stained by this ink, used to identify voters and prevent fraud. [[Nader Nadery]], of the [[Free and Fair Election Foundation of Afghanistan]] (FEFA) said two voters had each lost their finger in southern Kandahar province.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/6072785/Taliban-fighters-chopped-fingers-off-Afghan-voters-say-election-observers.html "Taliban fighters 'chopped fingers off Afghan voters' say election observers - Taliban fighters carried out their threat to chop fingers off Afghan voters, election observers said"]</ref>
In the capital city [[Kabul]], militants took over a building before being killed after a two-hour shootout. The capital was also reported to have been hit by at least five bomb blasts.<ref name=twoclaim/><ref name=tout/><ref name=amid/>
Two British soldiers and one U.S. soldier were also killed in separate roadside bomb blasts in the southern and eastern parts of Afghanistan on election day.<ref name=USbrit/>
Ichal Supriadi, an election observation supervisor with the Asian Network for Free Elections, reported that security fears had grounded many international observers, and that their election observation center had received many reports from their ground observers of people being discouraged from going out to vote.<ref name=mixed/>
====The worst violence in 15 years==== {{quote|text="''Polling day recorded the highest number of attacks and other forms of intimidation for some 15 years. Regrettably, 31 civilians were killed, including 11 IEC officials as well as 18 Afghan National Police (ANP) and eight Afghan National Army (ANA) personnel.''"|sign=AIHRC-[[United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan|UNAMA]] report, October 21, 2009<ref name=UNAMA/>}}
In a report dated October 21, 2009, issued after the release of the final certified election results for the August 20 vote, the [[United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan|UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan]] (UNAMA) and [[Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission]] (AIHRC) stated that on election day Afghanistan had suffered the highest number of attacks and intimidation the country had seen in ''some 15 years''. The timeframe of 15 years, going back to around August 1994, coincides with [[Ahmed Rashid]]'s description from [http://www.bookbrowse.com/excerpts/index.cfm?fuseaction=printable&book_number=888 "''Taliban: Militant Islam, Oil and Fundamentalism in Central Asia''"] of when "''Afghanistan was in state of virtual disintegration just before the Taliban emerged at the end of 1994. The country was divided into warlord fiefdoms and all the warlords had fought, switched sides and fought again in a bewildering array of alliances, betrayals and bloodshed.''"<ref name=UNAMA>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/EGUA-7X3PBQ?OpenDocument |title=AIHRC-UNAMA Joint Monitoring of Political Rights, Presidential and Provincial Council Elections, Third Report, 1 Aug – Oct 21 2009 |publisher=Reliefweb.int |date=2009-10-21 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=oil>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bookbrowse.com/excerpts/index.cfm?fuseaction=printable&book_number=888 |title=Taliban: Militant Islam, Oil and Fundamentalism in Central Asia |publisher=Bookbrowse.com |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
===Violence in the aftermath of the vote=== {{quote|text="''The highest level of civilian casualties since the fall of the Taleban in 2002 has been registered in Afghanistan in the period around the elections.''"|sign=Amnesty International, August 27, 2009<ref name=bombing>{{Cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/afghanistan-kandahar-bombing-and-nato-clinic-attack-highlight-increasing |title=Afghanistan: Kandahar bombing and NATO clinic attack, highlight increasing danger to civilians |publisher=Amnesty.org |accessdate=2010-04-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410184022/http://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/afghanistan-kandahar-bombing-and-nato-clinic-attack-highlight-increasing |archivedate=April 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>}}
On August 25, 2009, a few hours after the first preliminary results were released, a cluster of vehicle bombs detonated together in a massive explosion that killed at least 43 people and wounded at least 65 in [[Kandahar]] city, in the bloodiest attack since July 2008. The force of the giant blast, at the center of the city in a district that includes U.N. facilities and an Afghan intelligence office, caused houses and buildings around to collapse, shattering windows around the city, and sending flames shooting into the sky. People miles outside of town felt the rumble. The main target appeared to be a Japanese company that had recently taken over a contract to build a road that insurgents had stalled for several months. A Taliban spokesman denied responsibility, saying the group condemned the attack.<ref name=kills41>[http://www.kansascity.com/news/world/story/1406087.html Explosion in Afghanistan kills at least 41] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/presidential-runoff-could-spell-trouble-for-afghanistan/article1264308/ |title=Presidential runoff could spell trouble for Afghanistan |work=The Globe and Mail |accessdate=2010-04-07 |location=Toronto, Canada |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090829161404/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/presidential-runoff-could-spell-trouble-for-afghanistan/article1264308/ |archive-date=August 29, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=widens>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hvWEqwq3CrRvaQCmt21MfoYhjZJQD9AAJ9M82 Karzai widens lead over Abdullah in Afghan vote] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907194704/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hvWEqwq3CrRvaQCmt21MfoYhjZJQD9AAJ9M82 |date=September 7, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=seven>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/30/weekinreview/30filkins.html "Seven Days That Shook Afghanistan"], ''The New York Times''</ref>
On the same day, another bomb blast in southern Afghanistan killed four U.S. soldiers, bringing the total number of foreign troop deaths in Afghanistan this year to 295, making the 2009 death toll for foreign forces in Afghanistan the highest in the [[War in Afghanistan (2001-present)|eight-year war]] since the 2001 U.S. invasion.<ref name=kills41/><ref name=seven/>
On August 26, 2009, the justice ministry director of [[Kunduz province]], Sayed Jahangir, was killed by a bomb planted in his car in northern Afghanistan.<ref name=widens/>
On August 27, 2009, [[Amnesty International]] issued a statement saying: "As uncertainty surrounds the outcome of presidential elections in Afghanistan, civilians are at greater danger than at any time since the fall of the Taleban."
August 2009 ended as the deadliest month for U.S. troops in Afghanistan since the U.S. invasion in 2001. At least 51 American soldiers were killed in the month of the election, the highest monthly toll for the U.S. in the nearly eight-year-long war, surpassing the previous high of 45 in July. The month was also the worst in the war in terms of the overall death toll for all foreign military troops, with 77 deaths. Along with 76 deaths in July, the two months were by far the deadliest for the foreign military troops in Afghanistan, according to figures from icasualties.org.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/08/31/2048560.aspx |title=August deadliest month for U.S. military |publisher=Firstread.msnbc.msn.com |date=2009-08-31 |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928234410/http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/08/31/2048560.aspx |archivedate=September 28, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.icasualties.org/oef/ |title=Coalition Military Fatalities By Year and Month |publisher=Icasualties.org |accessdate=2010-04-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406083558/http://icasualties.org/oef/ |archivedate=April 6, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On September 12, 2009, a day on which the IEC was to have announced the first full preliminary results, waves of attacks engulfed Afghanistan. At least 66 people – including 24 civilians, 5 U.S. soldiers, and 26 Afghan policemen, soldiers, and guards – were killed in violence that swept across the country. The bloodshed seemed to demonstrate the ability of insurgents, including the Taliban, to carry out attacks in most parts of the country despite the surge to a record number of foreign military troops in the eight-year war.<ref name=engulf>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/13/world/asia/13afghan.html?hp "Wave of Attacks Engulfs Afghanistan"], ''The New York Times''</ref><ref name=dozens>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/homepageCrisis/idUSISL479504._CH_.2400 |title=Afghan attacks kill dozens; Karzai leads in poll |agency=Reuters |date=2009-09-12 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=spate>{{Cite web |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-09-12-voa12.cfm |title=Spate of Attacks Across Afghanistan Kills Dozens |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2009-09-12 |accessdate=2010-04-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330235410/http://www1.voanews.com/english/2009-09-12-voa12.cfm |archivedate=March 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=press>{{Cite news|author=Declan Walsh |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/13/hamid-karzai-power-sharing-afghanistan |title=Pressure grows in Afghanistan for Hamid Karzai to strike a deal |work=Guardian |location=UK |date= 2009-09-13|accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
===Possible ethnic imbalance=== The lack of security and its effects on voter registration, polling station accessibility, and voter turnout – mainly in regions populated by Afghanistan's [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] tribes, which make up 32-37% of the country's population – have raised serious concerns about an ethnic imbalance in the Afghan election.<ref name=farce/><ref name=qtime>{{Cite web|last=Margolis |first=Eric |url=http://www.torontosun.com/comment/columnists/eric_margolis/2009/08/23/10569911-sun.html |title=Quittin' time in Afghanistan |website=Toronto Sun |date=2009-08-23 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=marred/><ref name=mock>{{Cite news|author=Rosie DiManno |url=https://www.thestar.com/News/World/article/686508 |title=Afghan vote called 'mockery' |work=Toronto Star |date= 2009-08-26|accessdate=2010-04-07 }}</ref>
{{quote|text="''There are districts that I am 100 percent sure no government worker can go to - But you are telling me that still so many people registered? I don't believe it.''"|sign=Roshanak Wardak, Afghan member of parliament from Wardak Province<ref name=marred/>}}
According to leaders and residents of [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] districts, many voter registration centers in their districts never opened during the registration period and few people even left their homes, let alone registered. Provincial officials have also said that election registration teams rarely, if ever, dared to venture outside of the district capitals.<ref name=marred/>
In the province of [[Maidan Wardak Province|Wardak]], with six of the province's eight districts controlled by insurgents, this resulted in the two [[Hazara people|Hazara]]-dominated districts of the province forming the bulk of the new voters registered. Independent Election Commission (IEC) Deputy Chief Electoral Officer Zekra Barakzai stated that "the registration numbers in Pashtun districts are very low."<ref name=marred/>
According to Habibullah Rafeh, a policy analyst with the Afghan Academy of Sciences, there could be an ethnic imbalance if the same problem was reproduced in other Pashtun regions of Afghanistan.<ref name=marred/>
In Helmand province, where 62% of the population is [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] and where U.S. Marines conducted major offensives, only 75 people were found to have been registered in one town of 2,000 residents.<ref name=fraud/>
For those that did register to vote, the absence of polling stations because of lack of security may have been the next obstacle. In [[Helmand]] province, Haji Mohammad, from Marja district, said that he sold all his family’s voting cards because there were no polling stations in their area.<ref name=buy/>
On the day before the election, Afghan election officials ordered 443 polling stations within insurgent territory in the Pashtun-dominated provinces of [[Paktika]], [[Paktia]], [[Khost Province|Khost]], [[Zabul]], [[Helmand]] and [[Kandahar Province|Kandahar]] to stay closed because of the lack of security. While the Afghan election commission had until recently presented a figure of 7,000 polling stations, on election day it reported that only 6,200 polling stations had actually operated.<ref name=shut/><ref name=knockout/>
Compounded with its effects on voter registration and polling station accessibility, the lack of security also seems to have been a major factor in the much [[#Low voter turnout|lower voter turnout]] in the [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]]-dominated south of the country, where turnout was as low as 5–10%, effectively disenfranchising the region.<ref name=qtime/><ref name=twoclaim/><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/22/world/asia/22kabul.html "Afghan Election Poses New Tests for Washington"], ''The New York Times''</ref>
On election day, Abdul Hamid, a tribal elder from [[Paghman District]] – a mostly [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]] district bordering Wardak province – was reported as insisting that 40 to 50% of eligible [[Paghman District|Paghman]] voters had not received voting cards, and therefore could not cast a ballot.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/212916/ |title=Anti-Climax in Afghanistan |website=Newsweek |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928045812/http://www.newsweek.com/id/212916 |archivedate=September 28, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aims.org.af/afg/dist_profiles/unhcr_district_profiles/centra/kabul/paghmani.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051027173613/http://www.aims.org.af/afg/dist_profiles/unhcr_district_profiles/centra/kabul/paghmani.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-10-27 |title=UNHCR profile for Paghman District |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-04-07 }}</ref>
==Election fraud== Starting in December 2008, journalist [[Anand Gopal]] and others have reported extensively on the widespread instances of fraud in the voter registration process, with the registration rolls including "phantom voters" and multiple registration cards issued to a single registrant, amongst numerous other problems.<ref name=shut>{{Cite news|last=Farmer |first=Ben |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/6050245/Afghan-polling-stations-shut-amid-fears-of-voting-fraud.html |title=Afghan polling stations shut amid fears of voting fraud |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=marred/>
Two days before the election, an investigation by the [[BBC]] also found and reported evidence of widespread [[electoral fraud]] and corruption in the Afghan presidential election.<ref name=buy/><ref name=marred/><ref name=unearth>{{Cite news|last=Pannell |first=Ian |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8207315.stm |title=Afghan election fraud is unearthed |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-08-18 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref>
===Voting cards being sold=== After being informed that voting cards were being sold in the capital, [[Kabul]], an Afghan working for the BBC posed as a potential buyer and was offered one thousand voting cards on the spot, for $10 (£6) per card. Samples provided were all authentic with the name, photo and home details of the voter on them.<ref name=unearth/> Other parties also offered to sell the BBC investigators thousands of votes, and some sellers have even been arrested by the authorities.<ref name=unearth/>
A flourishing black market in voter registration cards has also sprung up across the south of Afghanistan where they were being sold for £6 to £18 each.<ref name=shut/> The Free and Fair Election Foundation of Afghanistan (FEFA), an independent election monitoring organisation, had also collected evidence of election fraud, particularly in the voter registration process.<ref name=buy/><ref name=unearth/> The monitoring group found that in many places people were being issued multiple voting cards, that voting cards were often issued for children, and that stacks of voting cards were given to men who falsely claimed that they were for women in their households.<ref name=unearth/> Long lists of imaginary female relatives were found to have been concocted during an attempt to update the electoral roll. In Kandahar, "Britney Jamilia Spears" appeared among the names registered.<ref name=kandahar/> FEFA found that multiple registrations of a single person were taking place in at least 40% of all centers in one phase of the registration drive, and in one case, investigators found that about 500 voting registration cards were given to just one individual in [[Badghis province]].<ref name=marred/>
The independent election observers also reported that as many as one in five registrations were for people under the voting age – in many cases as young as 12 years old.<ref name=scheme>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=48142 |title=Karzai and Warlords Mount Massive Vote Fraud Scheme |publisher=Ipsnews.net |date=2009-08-19 |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524074225/http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=48142 |archivedate=May 24, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> According to a pre-election report by the Afghanistan Analyst Network, a Kabul-based group of foreign experts, as many as three million voters on the register were feared to not exist. The huge numbers of vote cards issued for phantom voters have raised concerns about massive electoral fraud.<ref name=insult>{{Cite news|author= |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/aug/23/havana-marking-afghanistan-election |title=It is insulting to Afghans to declare their election a success |work=Guardian |location=UK |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}</ref><ref name=kandahar/><ref name=tout/> Shahrzad Akbar, a senior analyst with FEFA, stated that because the monitoring body was only able to investigate a few parts of the country, the election irregularities and abuses could be even more widespread:
<blockquote> "''We couldn't observe how it went in every single district or village. I am sure that there are cases of multiple card distribution that we don't know about. But those incidents that we do know about caused us enough concern to contact the Independent Election Commission and say, 'please prevent this!'''"<ref name=unearth/> </blockquote>
===Bribes being offered=== There has also been evidence that people working for candidates have deliberately tried to influence the outcome of the election by offering bribes to buy large numbers of votes.<ref name=unearth/>
In [[Baghlan province]], a tribal elder and former military commander described how the voter fraud scheme worked. Within the hierarchical structure of Afghanistan, key local leaders like him have the ability to persuade large numbers of people to vote for one candidate or another. He reported that he and other local leaders had been approached by teams from the two leading contenders of the presidential election with monetary bribes:
<blockquote> "''If one candidate gives $10,000, then the other gives $20,000 and a third one offers even more. It has become such a lucrative and competitive business. I don't know where they get their money from.''"<ref name=unearth/> </blockquote>
According to a U.S. government-funded poll released the week before the poll, the two leading contenders in the election were [[Hamid Karzai]], the Pashtun incumbent, and Dr. [[Abdullah Abdullah]], the former foreign minister with strong ties to the former [[Northern Alliance]].<ref name=halted/><ref name=shut/>
