page.title: Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act (Estonia)

revision.text:
[[Estonia]]'s '''Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act''', passed on June 11, 1997, is a law designed to fulfill that country's treaty obligations under the [[Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs]], the [[Convention on Psychotropic Substances]], and the [[United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances]]. The Act establishes four Schedules of drugs. Schedule I comprises "narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances the handling of which is prohibited in Estonia except in the cases prescribed by law." Schedules II, III, IV comprise [[prescription drug]]s.
The Act divides [[wiktionary:Precursor|precursor]]s into two categories: Schedule I (bases) and Schedule II ([[reagent]]s).
The Act provides for drug addiction prevention and treatment, including [[involuntary hospitalization]].
==References== *[http://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/legal_library/ee/legal_library_1999-08-30_1999-59.html Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act]. [[Category:Drug control law]] [[Category:1997 in law]] [[Category:1997 in Estonia]] [[Category:Estonian law]]

page.title: Neutral powers during World War II

revision.comment: Alter: isbn, url. Add: chapter. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
[[File:Map of participants in World War II.png|{{plainlist|style=padding-left: 0.6em;| {{Legend|#63B74E|[[Allies of World War II|Allied Powers]]}} {{Legend|#66FF00|Allied Powers after the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]]}} {{Legend|#2AACF6|[[Axis Powers]]}}}}|thumb|300px]] The '''neutral powers''' were countries that remained [[Neutral country|neutral]] during [[World War II]]. Some of these countries had large colonies abroad or had great economic power. Spain had just been through [[Spanish Civil War|its civil war]], which ended on 1 April 1939 (five months prior to the [[Invasion of Poland]])—a war that involved several countries that subsequently [[Participants in World War II|participated in World War II]].
During World War II, the neutral powers took no official side, hoping to avoid attack. However, Portugal, Sweden, Colombia, and Switzerland all helped the [[Allies of World War II|Allied Powers]] by supplying "voluntary" brigades {{citation needed|date=August 2018}} to the [[United Kingdom]], while Spain avoided the Allies in favor of the [[Axis Powers|Axis]]. Ireland generally favoured the Allied side, as with the United States. The United States remained neutral until December 8, 1941, a day following the [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|sneak attack by Japan on Pearl Harbor]].
The [[Lateran Treaty]] between Italy and the Vatican, signed in 1929, required that the Pope maintain "perpetual neutrality in international relations"—making the [[Vatican City]] a neutral state.
Several countries suffered invasions in spite of their efforts to be neutral. These included [[Nazi Germany]]'s [[Occupation of Denmark|invasion of Denmark]] [[Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|and Norway]] on 9 April 1940—[[Battle of Belgium|then Belgium]], [[History of the Netherlands (1939–1945)|the Netherlands]], [[German occupation of Luxembourg in World War II|and Luxembourg]] on 10 May 1940. On the same day, 10 May 1940, the British [[Invasion of Iceland|invaded Iceland]] and established an occupying force ([[Invasion of Iceland#United States occupation force|subsequently replaced]] by the then-neutral United States). In the eastern Baltic, the Soviet Union [[Occupation of the Baltic states|invaded Lithuania]] on 15 June 1940 and [[Occupation of the Baltic states|Latvia and Estonia]] on 17 June. In the Balkans, the [[Italo-Greek War]] began on 28 October 1940 and [[invasion of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia was invaded]] in April 1941. Iran was also [[Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran|attacked and occupied]] by Britain and the Soviet Union in August 1941.
See also the [[History of Afghanistan|histories of Afghanistan]], [[History of Andorra#20th century|Andorra]], [[History of Guatemala#Early 20th century|Guatemala]], [[History of Liechtenstein#Liechtenstein during the World Wars|Liechtenstein]], [[History of Saudi Arabia#Abdul Aziz and the foundation of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabia]] and [[History of Yemen#Mutawakkilite kingdom and southern protectorates|Yemen]] during this period.
==Continent== ===Europe===
====Ireland==== {{Main|Irish neutrality during World War II}} {{See also|Bombing of Dublin in World War II}}
*{{Flag|Ireland}} – The policy of [[Irish neutrality]] during [[World War II]] was adopted by the [[Oireachtas]] (legislature of [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]) at the instigation of [[Éamon de Valera]], the [[Taoiseach]] ([[head of government]]) upon the outbreak of hostilities in Europe. It was maintained throughout the conflict, in spite of [[Bombing of Dublin in World War II|several German air raids]] (understood to be by aircraft that missed their intended targets in Britain or Northern Ireland) and [[MV Kerlogue|attacks on Ireland's shipping fleet by Allies and Axis alike]]. De Valera refrained from joining either the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] or [[Axis powers of World War II|Axis powers]].
====Portugal==== {{Main|Portugal in World War II}}
*{{Flag|Estado Novo (Portugal)|name=Portugal}} – Portugal was officially neutral during the World War II. However, it maintained a close relationship with the UK, due to the [[Anglo-Portuguese Alliance|alliance]] it had for the last six hundred years, which is the longest lasting military alliance in history. The [[Estado Novo (Portugal)|Estado Novo]] sought neutrality as a strategy to keep Spain neutral and prevent it from joining the Axis. Portugal continued trading with countries from both sides of the conflict throughout the war. In the second half of the war, it let the Allies use bases in the [[Azores]] to fight German submarines, because Salazar feared already an allied invasion over the Azores.
Colonies of Portugal: ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Portuguese Angola|Angola]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Colonial Cape Verde|Cape Verde]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Portuguese Guinea]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Portuguese India]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Colonial Macau|Macau]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Portuguese Mozambique|Mozambique]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Colonial São Tomé and Príncipe|São Tomé and Príncipe]] ::*{{Flagicon|Portugal}} [[Portuguese Timor]] (Occupied by [[Japan]] from 1942 to 1944)
====Spain==== {{Main|Spain in World War II}}
*{{Flag|Spanish State|1938|name=Spain}} – Franco sent the [[Division Azul|Blue Division]] to fight for the Axis on the Eastern Front.
====Sweden==== {{Main|Sweden during World War II}}
*{{Flag|Sweden}} – The Swedish government supported Finland during the [[Winter War]]. The later [[transit of German troops through Finland and Sweden]] and [[Swedish iron-ore mining during World War II]] helped the German war effort. During the [[Liberation of Finnmark]] it sent [[Norwegian police troops in Sweden during World War II|Norwegian "police" troops]] over the border to link up with [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] forces. At the end of the war it was preparing to invade Norway and Denmark with the Allies should the occupying Wehrmacht forces refuse to accept a general German armistice.
====Switzerland==== {{Main|Switzerland during the World Wars}}
*{{Flag|Switzerland}} – Switzerland maintained its neutrality so as to protect its own [[Banking in Switzerland|banking interests]] from plunder by the Axis. It also depended on German coal, with 10 million tons imported during the war, making up 41% of Swiss energy supplies. Often, Swiss soldiers opened fire on Axis bombers invading their [[airspace]]. On several occasions, Switzerland also shot down Allied planes. Throughout the war, cities in Switzerland were "accidentally" bombed by both Axis and Allied airplanes. [[Adolf Hitler]] did indeed [[Operation Tannenbaum|plan to invade Switzerland]], but Switzerland [[National Redoubt (Switzerland)|had formed complex fortifications]] and amassed hundreds of thousands of soldiers in the mountains to thwart any Axis invasion. Because of the extreme mountainous conditions in Switzerland, Hitler decided to [[Battle of Britain|bombard the United Kingdom]] rather than engage in a costly war with Switzerland.
====Lithuania==== {{Main|Resistance in Lithuania during World War II}}
*{{Flag|Lithuania}} – Lithuania, along with its [[Baltic states|Baltic]] neighbours [[Latvia]] and [[Estonia]], jointly declared their neutrality on November 18, 1938, in [[Riga]], at the Conference of Baltic Foreign Ministers with their respective parliaments passing neutrality laws later that year.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Liekis|first1=Šarūnas|title=1939: The Year that Changed Everything in Lithuania's History|date=2010|publisher=Rodopi|location=New York|isbn=978-9042027626|pages=119–122|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ST3LrBPOM4gC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=Lithuanian+Neutrality+Law#v=onepage&q=Lithuanian%20Neutrality%20Law&f=false|language=en}}</ref> Despite that, [[Occupation of the Baltic states|all three Baltic states were occupied]] twice by the [[Soviet Union]] and once by [[Nazi Germany]].
====Latvia==== {{Main|Military history of Latvia during World War II}}
*{{Flag|Latvia}} – Latvia, along with its [[Baltic states|Baltic]] neighbours [[Lithuania]] and [[Estonia]], jointly declared their neutrality on November 18, 1938, in [[Riga]], at the Conference of Baltic Foreign Ministers with their respective parliaments passing neutrality laws later that year.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neiburgs|first1=Uldis|title=Soviet occupation|url=http://okupacijasmuzejs.lv/en/history/1-soviet-occupation/latvia-during-world-war-ii|website=Latvijas Okupācijas muzejs|accessdate=17 December 2017}}</ref> Despite that, [[Occupation of the Baltic states|all three Baltic states were occupied]] twice by the [[Soviet Union]] and once by [[Nazi Germany]].
====Estonia==== {{Main|Estonia in World War II}}
*{{Flag|Estonia}} – Estonia, along with its [[Baltic states|Baltic]] neighbours [[Lithuania]] and [[Latvia]], jointly declared their neutrality on November 18, 1938, in [[Riga]], at the Conference of Baltic Foreign Ministers with their respective parliaments passing neutrality laws later that year.<ref>[http://www.letton.ch/lvx_38.htm Estonian Neutrality Law of December lst, 1938]</ref> Despite that, [[Occupation of the Baltic states|all three Baltic states were occupied]] twice by the [[Soviet Union]] and once by [[Nazi Germany]].
====Microstates====
=====Andorra=====
*{{Flag|Andorra}}
=====Liechtenstein=====
*{{Flag|Liechtenstein}}
=====Monaco=====
*{{Flag|Monaco}} (occupied by Italy and later Germany)
=====San Marino=====
*{{Flag|San Marino}} (briefly occupied by Germany, 17–20 September 1944; declared war on Germany, 21 September 1944)
=====Vatican City=====
*{{Flag|Vatican City}}, see [[Vatican City in World War II]]
===Asia=== ====Afghanistan==== *{{Flag|Kingdom of Afghanistan|1931|name=Afghanistan}} remained neutral throughout World War II.
====Iran==== *{{Flag|Iran}}, see [[Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran]] even though was neutral but occupied by Allies.
====Saudi Arabia====
* {{Flag|Saudi Arabia|1938}} severed diplomatic contacts with Germany on 11 September 1939, and with Japan in October 1941. Although officially neutral, the Saudis provided the Allies with large supplies of oil. Diplomatic relations with the United States were established in 1943. [[Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia|King Abdul Aziz Al-Saud]] was a personal friend of Franklin D. Roosevelt. The Americans were then allowed to build an air force base near [[Dhahran]].<ref>{{Cite book|page=382|title=The Asian Century: A History of Modern Nationalism in Asia|author=Jan Romein|publisher=University of California Press|date=1962}}</ref> Saudi Arabia declared war on Germany on 28 February 1945 and Japan on 1 April 1945, but no military actions resulted from the declaration.
====Tibet==== *{{Flag|Tibet|1912}} ([[Tibet (1912–51)|unrecognised]]; claimed by China but ''de facto'' independent), remained neutral throughout [[World War II]]
====Turkey==== {{Main|Single-party period of the Republic of Turkey#1938–1950: İnönü (National Chief)|History of the Republic of Turkey#World War II}}
*{{Flag|Turkey}} was neutral until several months before the end of the war, at which point it joined the Allies. Prior to the outbreak of war, Turkey signed a Mutual Aid Pact with France and Britain in 1939. After the German invasion of France, however, Turkey remained neutral, relying on a clause excusing them if military action might bring conflict with the USSR, which, after the division of Poland, Turkey feared. Then, in June 1941, after neighbouring Bulgaria joined the Axis and allowed Germany to move troops through to invade [[Invasion of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] and [[Battle of Greece|Greece]], Turkey signed a [[German–Turkish Treaty of Friendship|treaty of friendship]] with Germany. Turkey was an important producer of [[chromite]] — a key ingredient in the manufacture of [[stainless steel]] and [[refractory brick]] — to which the Germans had limited access. Sale of chromite to Germany or to the Allies (who had access to other sources, and mainly bought Turkish chromite in order to preclude its sale to Germany) was the key issue in Turkey's negotiations with both sides. Turkey halted its sales to Germany in April 1944 and broke off relations in August. In February 1945, after the Allies made its invitation to the inaugural meeting of the United Nations (along with the invitations of several other nations) conditional on full belligerency, Turkey declared war on the Axis powers, but no Turkish troops ever saw combat.
====Yemen====
*{{Flag|Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen|name=Yemen}} remained neutral throughout World War II
==Conclusion== Portugal, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland held to the concept of [[armed neutrality]], and continuously amassed soldiers to defend their nation's [[sovereignty]] from potential invasion. Thus, they maintained the right to become belligerent if attacked while in a state of neutrality. The concept of ''neutrality in [[war]]'' is narrowly defined and puts specific constraints on the neutral party in return for the internationally recognized right to remain neutral. A wider concept is that of [[non-belligerence]]. The basic [[international law]] covering [[Neutral territory|neutral territories]] is the [[Hague Conventions (1899 and 1907)|Second Hague Convention]]. It is important to note that a ''neutral country'' takes no side in a war between other parties, and in return hopes to avoid being attacked by either of them. A ''neutralist policy'' aims at neutrality in case of an armed conflict that could involve the party in question. A ''neutralist'' is an advocate of neutrality in [[international relations|international affairs]]. The concept of ''neutrality in conflicts'' is distinct from [[Non-Aligned Movement|non-alignment]], i.e., the willful desistance from [[military alliance]]s in order to preserve neutrality in case of war, and perhaps with the hope of preventing a war altogether.
In a study of Spain, Switzerland and Sweden during WWII, Eric Golson found that they engaged in economic [[realpolitik]], as they traded with both the Axis and the Allied Powers.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Economic History of Warfare and State Formation|last=Golson|first=Eric|date=2016|publisher=Springer, Singapore|isbn=9789811016042|series=Studies in Economic History|pages=259–278|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-981-10-1605-9_11|chapter = Neutrality in War}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Participants in World War II]] *[[Allies of World War II]] *[[Axis powers]] *[[Declarations of war during World War II]] *[[Latin America during World War II]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *Karsh, E. "Neutrality and Small States." 1989. *Gabriel, J. M. "The American Conception of Neutrality After 1941." 1989. *http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1E1-neutral.html
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121009230811/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/lawofwar/hague05.htm Second Hague Convention]

Professor '''Peter Drahos''' is an Australian academic and researcher specializing in the areas of [[intellectual property]] and global business regulation amongst others. He is the Director of the Centre for Governance of Knowledge and Development and was formerly the Head of Program of the Regulatory Institutions Network at the [[Australian National University]]. He has served in an advisory capacity to various governments and international organisations on intellectual property issues and holds a Chair in Intellectual Property at the [[University of London]]. He is also a member of the Australian Bar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cgkd.anu.edu.au/menus/people_staff&students.php#drahos |title=ANU - Centre for Governance of Knowledge and Development (CGKD) - Professor Peter Drahos |publisher=Cgkd.anu.edu.au |date=2009-02-19 |accessdate=2012-01-04}}</ref> He was a 2004 recipient, along with [[John Braithwaite (criminologist)|John Braithwaite]], of the [[University of Louisville]] [[Grawemeyer Award]] for Ideas Improving World Order.<ref name=grawemeyer.org>{{cite web|title=2004- John Braithwaite and Peter Drahos|url=http://grawemeyer.org/worldorder/previous-winners/2004-john-brathwaite-and-Peter-Drahos.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812210759/http://grawemeyer.org/worldorder/previous-winners/2004-john-brathwaite-and-Peter-Drahos.html|archivedate=2014-08-12|df=}}</ref>
==Selected publications== === Books=== *''Information Feudalism: Who Controls the Knowledge Economy?'' (with John Braithwaite), The New Press, 2002 *''Global Intellectual Property Rights: Knowledge, Access and Development'', (with Ruth Mayne), Macmillan, 2002 *''Global Business Regulation, (with John Braithwaite)'', Cambridge University Press, 2000, received the 2004 University of Louisville [[Grawemeyer Award]] for Ideas Improving World Order. *''A Philosophy of Intellectual Property'', Dartmouth, 1996. (Translated into [http://www.qmipri.qmul.ac.uk/news/2015/items/148617.html Persian], Japanese, Spanish and Chinese)
===Articles=== *[http://www.anu.edu.au/fellows/pdrahos/articles/pdfs/2005a2ktimeforatreaty.pdf Time for a Treaty? 2005] *[http://www.anu.edu.au/fellows/pdrahos/articles/pdfs/1997thinkingstratippolicy.pdf Thinking Strategically about Intellectual Property Rights 1997] *[http://www.anu.edu.au/fellows/pdrahos/pdfs/2007fourlessonsfordevcountries.pdf Four Lessons for Developing Countries from the Trade Negotiations over Access to Medicine 2007]
==References== <references />
==External links== * {{cite web|url=http://www.anu.edu.au/fellows/pdrahos/ |title=Peter Drahos |publisher=ANU |date=2008-07-01 |accessdate=2012-01-04}}

{{lang-cy|Plaid Môr-leidr DU}} |leader2_title = Chair of the Board |leader2_name = [[Adrian Farrel]]{{cite web|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/leaders-office|title=Leaders Office - The Pirate Party|website=www.pirateparty.org.uk}} |founded = {{Start date|2009|07|30|df=yes}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/6011356/Pirate-Party-UK-now-registered-by-the-Electoral-Commission.html|title=Pirate Party UK now registered by the Electoral Commission|first=Emma|last=Barnett|publisher= |work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=11 August 2009|location=London}} |membership_year = 2017 |membership = {{decrease}} 420 |position = |colours = {{Color box|#660066|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|#000000|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|#FFFFFF|border=darkgray}}
[[Purple]], [[black]] and [[white]]{{cite web|url=https://pirateparty.org.uk/campaigns/activists/design |title=Design |publisher=The Pirate Party |date= |accessdate=3 December 2016}} }} The '''Pirate Party UK''' (often abbreviated '''PPUK'''; in {{lang-cy|Plaid Môr-leidr DU}}) is a [[List of political parties in the United Kingdom|political party]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. The Pirate Party's core policies are to bring about reform to copyright and patent laws, support privacy, reduce surveillance from government and businesses, and support [[freedom of speech]] and freedom of expression.{{cite web| url = https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/| title= Pirate Party UK| accessdate= 4 June 2012}}
- {{cite web|url=http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/interviews/350728/q-a-why-the-uk-needs-the-pirate-party|title=Q&A: Why the UK needs the Pirate Party|first=Stuart|last=Turton|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=12 August 2009|publisher= |website=[[PC Pro]]}}[https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/sites/default/files/library/OpenManifesto.pdf OUR OPEN MANIFESTO FOR THE SNAP GENERAL ELECTION] (Pirate Party UK, 2017 general election manifesto). Accessed via the Pirate Party UK's official website. Retrieved 7 April 2018. The party was established in July 2009. The first [[Party leader|leader]] of the party was Andrew Robinson, who stepped down in August 2010. [[Loz Kaye|Laurence "Loz" Kaye]] was elected to replace him in September 2010, and served until after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], when he stepped down.{{cite web|last1=Kaye|first1=Loz|authorlink1=Loz Kaye|title=Moving On|url=https://pirateparty.org.uk/blogs/loz-kaye/moving|website=Pirate Party UK|accessdate=5 August 2015|date=9 May 2015}} Following Kaye's resignation, a leadership election was held, with Cris Chesha being elected leader and David A Elston being elected the party's first deputy leader.{{cite web|title=Pirate Party UK announces appointments to the NEC, and Board of Governors|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/press/pirate-party-uk-announces-appointments-nec-and-board-governors|website=Pirate Party UK|accessdate=9 July 2015}} ==History== Following [[The Pirate Bay trial]], a large surge in Pirate Party interest occurred around the world. After the success of the [[Pirate Party (Sweden)|Swedish Pirate Party]] in the summer [[European Parliament election, 2009|2009 European election]]s, there was a sudden growth of Pirate Party organisations across Europe (notably in Germany and France) and beyond. Forum membership soared. The official formation of the Pirate Party in the UK followed shortly after the European elections{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2009-06/08/pirate-party-wins-european-parliament-seat.aspx|title=Pirate Party wins European Parliament seat|last=Scott|first=Katie|date=8 June 2009|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] UK|accessdate=17 August 2009}}
- {{Cite news|url=http://www.revolutionmagazine.com/news/911708/Pirate-Bay-fans-voice-copyright-issues/|title=Pirate Bay fans get voice on copyright issues|last=McCormick|first=Andrew|date=8 June 2009|work=Revolution |publisher=[[Brand Republic]]|accessdate=17 August 2009}} and the Pirate Party UK was officially registered on 30 July 2009.{{cite web| title = Register of political parties, Pirate Party UK| publisher = [[The Electoral Commission]]| url = http://registers.electoralcommission.org.uk/regulatory-issues/regpoliticalparties.cfmfrmGB=1&frmPartyID=900&frmType=partydetail| accessdate = 3 February 2010}}{{Dead link |date=June 2011 }}{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/8199143.stm|title=Pirate Party launches UK poll bid |date=13 August 2009|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=17 August 2009}}
- {{Cite news|url=http://www.techradar.com/news/internet/pirate-party-uk-sets-sail-624848|title=Pirate Party UK sets sail|last=Harris|first=Mark|date=11 August 2009|work=[[TechRadar]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|accessdate=17 August 2009}} In August 2009, it was claimed that Pirate Party UK was undergoing rapid growth similar to one the Swedish Pirate Party had enjoyed in early 2009. It was reported that it had been flooded with enquiries and at its peak around 100 people an hour were signing up to become party members. Donations had been coming in so fast that [[PayPal]] was concerned it was a fraudulent site.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/6027919/Hundred-people-an-hour-joining-Pirate-Party-UK.html|title='Hundred people an hour' joining Pirate Party UK|first=Emma|last=Barnett|accessdate=13 August 2009|date=13 August 2009|publisher= |website=[[Telegraph.co.uk]] |location=London}} On 30 March 2010, the party declared its intent to stand ten candidates across England and Scotland. However, to do so, further party funding would be required.{{cite web|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/press/pirate-party-uk-announces-parliamentary-candidates|title=PPUK Announces Parliamentary Candidates|publisher=Pirate Party UK}} On 27 April 2010, the party announced that it had nine official candidates on the ballot papers, as Mark Sims had missed the deadline because of the [[air travel disruption after the 2010 Eyjafjallajökull eruption]]. Following the resignation of first party leader Andrew Robinson,{{cite web|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/blog/editor/pirate-party-uk-one-year|title=The Pirate Party UK, One Year On|publisher=Pirate Party UK}} the composer and lecturer [[Loz Kaye|Laurence "Loz" Kaye]] was elected as the new leader on 26 September 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2010-09/28/pirate-party-leader|title=Loz Kaye elected leader of UK Pirate Party|work=[[Wired News]]|publisher=}}
- {{cite web|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/blog/editor/pirate-party-elects-new-leader|title=Pirate Party Elects New Leader'|publisher=Pirate Party UK}} In a message sent to members, Kaye stated his key aim as "building the political structure of the party".{{cite web|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/blog/lozkaye/message-new-leader|title=A Message From the New Leader|publisher=Pirate Party UK}} Previously, Kaye had been the election agent for candidate Tim Dobson who stood for Pirate Party UK in [[Manchester Gorton]]. In the run-up to the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], the Pirate Party [[crowdsourced]] its [[manifesto]] using [[Reddit]]. The process ran until 21 March 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/artsandculture/article/23927/1/pirate-party-is-crowdsourcing-its-manifesto-on-reddit|title=Pirate Party is crowdsourcing its manifesto on Reddit|last1=Gorton|first1=Thomas|work=Dazed|accessdate=5 August 2015}} Kaye stepped down as leader following the 2015 general election in May. With the role of deputy leader also being vacant, George Walkden, the party's nominating officer, was approved by the board of governors to serve as an interim leader until the party elected a new leader.{{cite web|url=https://pirateparty.org.uk/be-part-new-pirate-crew |title=Be a part of the new Pirate crew! |publisher=The Pirate Party |date= |accessdate=3 December 2016}} Following the leadership election, Cris Chesha was elected leader of the party and David Elston was elected the first deputy leader. Six new governors were elected, with six governors being re-elected. Rebecca Rae was elected to the role of campaigns officer on the NEC.{{cite web|title=Internal election results July 2015|url=https://community.pirateparty.org.uk/discussion/227/internal-election-results-july-2015|website=Pirate Party UK|accessdate=5 August 2015}} On 18 June, [[Andrew Norton (Pirate Party)|Andrew Norton]] stepped down as chair of the board, and was replaced by the deputy chair of the board, Andrew Robinson, the leader of the party from 2009 to 2010. On 29 July 2015, Will Tovey was elected as the next deputy chair of the board to replace Robinson. Will Tovey subsequently became chair of the board, and Adrian Farrel replaced him on 14 December 2016.{{cite web|title=The Board|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/party/how-we-work/board|website=Pirate Party UK|accessdate=5 August 2015}} The party's extended period without an elected NEC caught the attention of larger media outlets in October 2016 where Kaye and Elston gave comment.{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.co.uk/features/2016/10/pirate-party-growing-pains/|title=Pirate Party growing pains: Murder-suicide, a fetish model, and Alþingi|website=Ars Technica|publisher=David Meyeer|accessdate=24 October 2016}} ==Organisation== ===Leadership=== [[File:Loz.jpg|thumb|Pirate Party UK's former leader [[Loz Kaye]]]] {| class="wikitable" |- !# !Name !Leadership began !Leadership ended ! Notes |- |1 | Andrew Robinson || 30 July 2009 |23 August 2010 | |- |— |''Vacant'' |23 August 2010 |27 September 2010 | |- |2 | [[Loz Kaye]] || 27 September 2010 |9 May 2015 | |- |3 | George Walkden || 9 May 2015 |4 July 2015 | ''Interim leader'' |- |4 | Cris Chesha || 4 July 2015 |26 November 2015 | |- |— |''Vacant'' |26 November 2015 |10 February 2016 | |- |5 | David A Elston || 10 February 2016 |19 February 2016 | ''Acting leader'' |- |— |''Vacant'' |19 February 2016 |3 February 2017 | |- |5 | David A Elston || 3 February 2017 |26 October 2017 | ''Re-elected acting leader'' |- |6 | Harley Faggetter || 24 November 2017 ||| |} === Deputy Leadership === {| class="wikitable" |- !# !Name !Leadership began !Leadership ended ! Notes |- |1 | David A Elston || 4 July 2015 |19 February 2016 | |- |— |''Vacant'' |19 February 2016 |3 February 2017 | |- |1 | David A Elston || 3 February 2017{{Cite web |url=https://pirateparty.org.uk/nec-election-results-2017 |title=NEC Election Results 2017 |last=Chapman |first=Mark}} |26 October 2017 | ''Re-elected'' |- |2 | Mark Chapman || 24 November 2017{{Cite web |url=https://pirateparty.org.uk/nec-election-results-2017 |title=NEC Election Results 2017 |last=Chapman |first=Mark}} ||| |} ===Branches=== The Pirate Party UK has branches in many places around the United Kingdom. These include [[London]],{{cite web|url=https://london.pirateparty.org.uk/ |title=London — Pirate Party UK blog |publisher= |website=pirateparty.org.uk |accessdate=10 November 2014}} [[York]],{{cite web|url=https://york.pirateparty.org.uk/ |title=York — Pirate Party UK blog |publisher= |website=pirateparty.org.uk |accessdate=10 November 2014}} [[Greater Manchester]],{{cite web|url=https://manchester.pirateparty.org.uk/ |title=Manchester — Pirate Party UK blog |publisher= |website=pirateparty.org.uk |accessdate=10 November 2014}} [[Sheffield]]{{cite web|url=https://pirateparty.org.uk/sheffield |title=Know us, Like us, Vote for us |publisher=The Pirate Party |date= |accessdate=3 December 2016}} and [[Bury, Greater Manchester|Bury]].{{cite web|url=http://bury.pirateparty.org.uk/ |title=The Pirate Party in Bury |publisher= |website=Bury.pirateparty.org.uk |date=16 January 2014 |accessdate=3 December 2016}} ====Pirate Party Wales==== Pirate Party Wales ({{lang-cy|Plaid Môr-leidr Cymru}}) is a branch of the Pirate Party UK that covers the entirety of Wales and was founded in 2014 by David Anthony Elston. Pirate Party Wales supports increased recognition of the [[Welsh language]], including reform of the [[Welsh Language Act 1993]] and free Welsh courses for all Welsh nationals. It also supports further [[devolution]] to Wales and increased powers for the [[Welsh Assembly]].{{cite news|title=Pirate Party Wales: We need to become a digital dragon|url=http://dailywales.net/2015/01/07/pirate-party-wales-we-need-to-become-a-digital-dragon/|accessdate=14 April 2015|work=The Daily Wales|date=7 January 2015}} The only candidate to have stood in Wales so far is Elston who stood in [[Bridgend (UK Parliament constituency)|Bridgend]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]].{{cite web|title=Bridgend Constituency|url=https://wales.pirateparty.org.uk/spokesperson-for-wales/bridgend/|website=Pirate Party Wales|accessdate=14 April 2015}} === International affiliation === On 25 February 2015, the Pirate Party UK announced its withdrawal from its international affiliation, [[Pirate Party International]]. This announcement, consolidated by a vote of the board, followed [[Pirate Party Australia]]'s decision to leave earlier in the same month.{{cite web|url=https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/blogs/editor/ppuk-leaves-ppi|title=PPUK leaves PPI|website=Pirate Party UK|accessdate=28 May 2015}}
- {{cite news|url=http://piratetimes.net/ppuk-bids-farewell-to-ppi-guest-post/|title=PPUK Bids Farewell to PPI|last1=Halsall|first1=Andy|date=26 February 2015|work=Pirate Times|accessdate=28 May 2015}} ==Membership== [[File:PPUK-Membership.png|thumb|Pirate Party UK's membership trend]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Membership |- | 2009 || 590 |- | 2010 || 457 |- | 2011 || 224 |- | 2012 || 748 |- | 2013 || 557 |- | 2014 || 689{{cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/Api/Accounts/Documents/18573|publisher=[[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] |title=Pirate Party UK Statement of Accounts 2015 |accessdate=26 October 2017}} |- | 2015 || 766 |- | 2016 || 500{{cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/Api/Accounts/Documents/19351|publisher=Electoral Commission|title=Pirate Party UK Statement of Accounts 2016|accessdate=26 October 2017}} |- |2017 |420{{Cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/Api/Accounts/Documents/19654|title=Pirate Party UK Statement of Accounts for year ending 31 December 2017|publisher=Electoral Commission |last=|first=|date=29 April 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=14 October 2018}} |} ==Election results== {{Main|Pirate Party UK election results}} It has previously been noted by Robinson, the first Pirate Party UK leader, that the Pirate Party UK's chances of getting a candidate elected to the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|UK parliament]] are "pretty much close to zero", because of the [[first past the post]] system for electing MPs to Parliament. Instead, its immediate aim is to raise awareness among voters and politicians in the other political parties.{{Cite news|url=http://www.pcpro.co.uk/news/interviews/350728/q-a-why-the-uk-needs-the-pirate-party|title=Q&A: Why the UK needs the Pirate Party|last=Turton|first=Stuart|date=12 August 2009|work=[[PC Pro]]|accessdate=17 August 2009}} The Pirate Party UK contested its first election in 2010, standing nine candidates in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]]. The party also stood candidates in the [[Oldham East and Saddleworth by-election, 2011|2011 Oldham East and Saddleworth]] and [[Manchester Central by-election, 2012|2012 Manchester Central]] by-elections. The party also contested several [[Local government in the United Kingdom|local government]] elections and the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2011|2011 Scottish Parliament election]]. The party stood six candidates in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], and ten in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 snap general election]]. In general elections, none of its candidates has ever received more than one percent of the vote. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Year !Candidates !Votes !Seats |- |[[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010]] |9 |1,340 |{{Composition bar|0|650|#990099}} |- |[[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015]] |6 |1,130 |{{Composition bar|0|650|#990099}} |- |[[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017]] |10 |2,321 |{{Composition bar|0|650|#990099}} |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Pirate Party UK}} {{Portal|Freedom of speech}} *[https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/ Official Pirate Party of the United Kingdom website] *[https://www.pirateparty.org.uk/sites/default/files/library/OpenManifesto.pdf Official Pirate Party of the United Kingdom 2017 manifesto] *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/election-2017-39887923/general-election-2017-pirate-party-plans-for-web-surveillance General election 2017: Pirate Party plans for web surveillance]. [[File:Rizana assembly manuscript 804 p1.jpg|thumb|Rizana assembly manuscript 804 p1]]
The '''Placitum of Riziano''' ({{lang-it|Placito del Risano}}) was a dispute that took place c. 804 around the river Riziano, probably at [[Rižana]] in modern [[Slovenia]]. Legates sent by [[Charlemagne]] heard complaints by the leaders of [[Istria]] about the bishops and the duke of Istria, John. It is an important document for Istrian history. The document is believed to have been recorded on the orders of Fortunatus II, [[patriarch of Grado]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Krahwinkler |first1=Harald |date=25 April 2005 |title= Patriarch Fortunatus of Grado and the Placitum of Riziano |url=https://repozitorij.upr.si/IzpisGradiva.php?id=5381&lang=eng |journal=[[''Acta Histriae'']] |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=63-78 |publisher=Annales Publishing House|doi= |access-date=24 November 2017 }}</ref> A point of historiographical contention is the fact that only the leaders of the coastal towns of Istria were present; one explanation for this is that the issues being discussed (for example, the abolition of the right of the [[townspeople]] to fish) only affected the coast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.istrianet.org/istria/history/0000-0999AD/0804_placito/index.htm |title=Placito del Risano - 804 A.D.|last= |first= |date=20 March 2016 |website=<nowiki>IstriaNet.org</nowiki> |publisher= |access-date= 24 November 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
The Latin text has been edited many times, but the standard edition is by Manaresi <ref> ''I placiti del Regnum Italiae'', ed. C. Manaresi (Rome, 1955), vol. I, no. 17, pp. 48-56 </ref>. The text has been translated into various modern languages. <ref> French translation: Ph. Depreux, ''Les societes occidentales du milieu du VI a la fin du IX siecle'' (Rennes, 2002), pp. 293-99, [[http://books.openedition.org/pur/17383 | online]]; English translation: C. West, 'In The Time of the Greeks', [[http://turbulentpriests.group.shef.ac.uk/in-the-time-of-the-greeks-the-rizana-dispute-and-the-carolingian-byzantine-empires | Turbulent Priests]] </ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * F. Borri, 'Neighbours and relatives: the plea of Rizana as a source for Northern Adriatic elites', ''Mediterranean Studies'' 17 (2008),1-26 * T. S. Brown, ''Officers and Gentlemen and Officers: Imperial Administration and Aristocratic Power in Byzantine Italy, A.D.554-800'' (London, 1984) * J. Davis, ''Charlemagne’s Practice of Empire'' (Cambridge, 2015), pp. 102-4, 274-7 * M. Innes, ‘Framing the Carolingian Economy’, ''Journal of Agrarian Change'' 9 (2009), 42-58.
